subject: Re: [junit] testlisteners
msgSnippet: #: by Teemu Kanstrén s words the mind was *winged* :# ... Some of the last additions to TestNG (http://testng.org) was the possibility to add programatically,
messageBody:
#: by Teemu Kanstrén's words the mind was *winged* :#
> Kent,
>
> Thanks for the reply. Would you consider adding something like this in
> JUnit 4 so it is there if someone like me needs it someday? I'd need to
> get this working now with 3.8.1 but would still be nice to have it in the
> future supported by the framework more directly.
>
> I thought about modifying the TestCase tearDown method to call my
> "listener" code but then I realized not all tests might do the
> super.tearDown call if they override the method. As I haven't written all
> the tests I want to collect data for I can't control that. So I am
> thinking of just modifying the TestResult class that collects the results
> and adding my listener there as it supports TestListeners. Does anyone
> see problems with that? This would mean I take the junit source, add my
> code and build the jar to use with the projects I want to collect data
> for.
>
> Thanks,
>
> -Teemu
>
> On Thu, 23 Jun 2005, Kent Beck wrote:
>
>> Teemu,
>>
>> You are correct that there is no generic way to add TestListeners. We
>> discussed various mechanisms for doing so, but we never put any into
>> production.
>>
>> Sincerely yours,
>>
>> Kent Beck
>> Three Rivers Institute
>>
>> > -----Original Message-----
>> > From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
>> > Behalf Of Teemu Kanstrén
>> > Sent: Monday, June 20, 2005 12:42 PM
>> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>> > Subject: [junit] testlisteners
>> >
>> > Hello all,
>> >
>> > I am trying to gather some data from the execution of JUnit test
>> > cases. For this purpose I wish to add a piece of code to be
>> > called after
>> > each test has been run. I noticed that TestResult has a possibility to
>> > add such a piece of code through TestListener.
>> >
>> > However, adding the listener requires that I have access to the
>> > TestResult objects created. And these in turn are created in the
>> > TestRunner instances. And if I run my tests from an IDE or Ant, the
>> > runner used is out of my control.
>> >
>> > I am thinking I could just modify the TestResult to always add my
>> > listener in its constructor or something similar (maybe a static
>> > listener..). But I am not sure if this is the best solution.
>> >
>> > So I guess my questions are:
>> > -Did I understand the code correctly?
>> > -Is there a way for me to easily add such a listener,
>> > hopefully without
>> > messing too much with the JUnit sources?
>> > -Can anyone think of reasons why modifying TestResult to contain my
>> > listener would not work? Are there some cases or environments
>> > that modify
>> > the execution so they dont use the standard TestResult? For
>> > example Ant,
>> > etc..
>> >
>> > Thanks for your trouble,
>> >
>> > -Teemu
>

Some of the last additions to TestNG (http://testng.org) was the possibility to add programatically,
from the command line or Ant, some of the tricky listeners used by it. If you consider taking a look
at it you will find out (or I can help you ;-)) how easy this can be done.

:alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
